elements.content: A 3D porous metal−organic framework generating 1D channels, [Mn(NDC)(DEF)] n (1), has been prepared from the solvothermal reaction of MnII and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2NDC) in diethylformamide (DEF). When DEF molecules coordinating MnII, which occupy the channels, are removed from 1 by heating the crystal of 1 at 250 °C under vacuum for 18 h, structural change occurs as evidenced by X-ray powder diffraction patterns. Desolvated solid [Mn(NDC)] n (2), which contains coordinatively unsaturated MnII sites, reveals remarkable sorption capabilities for N2, H2, CO2, and CH4 gases and exhibits type I sorption behavior indicative of permanent microporosity.

elements.content: Open metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have received great attention because of their diverse architectures and potential applications in molecular adsorption and separation processes, ion exchange, catalysis, sensor technology, and optoelectronics. For the modular construction of MOFs, secondary building units (SBUs) with specific geometry have often been employed, and they make the design and prediction of molecular architectures simple and easy. For example, the SBU of an octahedral-shaped Zn4O cluster, which is formed from the solvothermal reaction of Zn2+ and carboxylic acid, furnishes 3D porous frameworks. In particular, MOFs with coordinatively unsaturated metal sites (CUMSs) are important because they are expected to be effective heterogeneous catalysts. However, the chance of finding a MOF that contains CUMSs and yet exhibits permanent porosity is extremely rare10 because the open structure easily collapses upon removal of the coordinating solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Open metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received great attention because of their diverse architectures and potential applications in molecular adsorption and separation processes, ion exchange, catalysis, sensor technology, and optoelectronics. For the modular construction of MOFs, secondary building units (SBUs) with specific geometry have often been employed, and they make the design and prediction of molecular architectures simple and easy. For example, the SBU of an octahedral-shaped Zn4O cluster, which is formed from the solvothermal reaction of Zn2+ and carboxylic acid, furnishes 3D porous frameworks. In particular, MOFs with coordinatively unsaturated metal sites (CUMSs) are important because they are expected to be effective heterogeneous catalysts. However, the chance of finding a MOF that contains CUMSs and yet exhibits permanent porosity is extremely rare10 because the open structure easily collapses upon removal of the coordinating solvent molecules.

elements.content: Here we report a 3D open MOF [Mn(NDC)(DEF)] n (1; NDC2- = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate; DEF = diethylformamide) and its desolvated solid [Mn(NDC)] n (2). Solid 2 contains coordinatively unsaturated MnII sites as evidenced by elemental analysis, IR spectra, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data as well as coordination ability of water molecules. It adsorbs some important gases such as N2, H2, CO2, and CH4, exhibiting permanent microporosity.

It adsorbs some important gases such as N2, H2, CO2, and CH4, exhibiting permanent microporosity.

Preparation of [Mn(NDC)(DEF)] n (1). Mn(NO3)2·nH2O (0.18 g, ca. 1.0 mmol) and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2NDC; 0.22 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in diethylformamide (DEF; 7 mL). The solution was placed in a Teflon vessel within the autoclave, heated at 105 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Pale-yellowish block-shaped crystals were formed, which were filtered off, washed with DEF, and dried in air. Yield:  88%. FT-IR (Nujol mull):  ν C  O(DEF), 1648; ν O  C  O, 1611(s), 1554(s) cm-1. UV/vis (diffuse reflectance, λmax):  330, 285 nm. Anal. Calcd for MnC17H17NO5:  C, 55.15; H, 4.63; N, 3.78. Found:  C, 55.17; H, 4.71; N, 3.50.

Experimental Section

 Preparation of [Mn(NDC)(DEF)]   n    (1). Mn(NO3)2⋅nH2O (0.18 g, ca. 1.0 mmol) and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2NDC; 0.22 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in diethylformamide (DEF; 7 mL). The solution was placed in a Teflon vessel within the  autoclave, heated at 105 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Pale-yellowish block-shaped crystals were formed, which were filtered off, washed with DEF, and dried in air. Yield: 88%. FT-IR (Nujol mull): ν C  O(DEF), 1648; ν O  C  O, 1611(s), 1554(s) cm-1. elements.content: Gas Sorption Measurements. The gas adsorption−desorption experiments were performed using an automated micropore gas analyzer Autosorb-1 (Quantachrome Instruments). The sample was pre-desolvated in a Schlenk tube at 250 °C under vacuum for 18 h. An exactly measured amount of the pre-desolvated sample was introduced into the gas sorption instrument, and the outgassing process was carried out under vacuum at 150 °C for 3 h. After the gas sorption measurement, the weight was measured again. The outgassing procedure was repeated at 150 °C on the same sample between experiments for ca. 2 h. All gases used were of 99.999% purity. The N2 gas sorption isotherm for the desolvated solid was monitored at 77 K by using liquid N2 at each equilibrium pressure by the static volumetric method. The H2 gas sorption isotherm was measured at 77 K by a similar procedure. Sorption isotherms for CO2 and CH4 were measured at both 195 and 273 K by using an acetone/dry ice slush and an ice/water bath, respectively. The sorption properties including the pore volume, pore size, and surface area were analyzed using Autosorb 1 for Windows 1.24 software.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. The single crystal of 1 was sealed in a glass capillary together with the mother liquor. Diffraction data were collected on an Enraf Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Preliminary orientation matrixes and unit cell parameters were obtained from the peaks of the first 10 frames and then refined using the whole data set. Frames were integrated and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects by using DENZO. The scaling and global refinement of crystal parameters were performed by SCALEPACK. No absorption correction was made. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement using the SHELXL-97 computer program. The positions of all non-H atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement factors. The H atoms were positioned geometrically and refined using a riding model. The crystallographic data and selected bond distances and angles are summarized in Tables and .

Preparation and X-ray Structure of 1. Pale-yellowish block-shaped crystals of 1 were prepared by heating the DEF solutions of Mn(NO3)2·nH2O and H2NDC at 105 °C for 24 h. The X-ray crystal structure of 1 is shown in Figure . In 1, MnII ions are bridged by carboxylato groups in parts a and b of Chart to form a 1D MnII chain that extends along the a direction. The intrachain Mn- -Mn distance is 3.805 Å. Each MnII is coordinated with six O atoms that belong to four carboxylato groups and one DEF, showing pseudo-octahedral coordination geometry. The carboxylato group O(1)−C(6)−O(2) acts as a tridentate (Chart b) and forms a four-membered chelate ring with Mn [O(1)−Mn−O(2) angle, 56.9°]. The Mn−O distances range from 2.080 to 2.324 Å. The 1D MnII chains are linked one to another via naphthalene rings of NDC2- to form a 3D framework that generates 1D channels of rhombic aperture with diagonal lengths of 21.5 Å × 10.5 Å. The effective window size of the channels is ca. 6.1 Å. The planes made of naphthalene rings of NDC2- run parallel to the (011) and (011̄) planes and meet across at the 1D MnII chains with a dihedral angle of 50.5°. Although 3D frameworks have been constructed from NDC2- and other metal ions such as Mg2+, Zn2+, and Ni2+, they show structures different from that of 1. The void space of the channels is filled with DEF molecules coordinating MnII ions. The void volume that may be generated after removal of the coordinating DEF molecules is 42.1% of the total volume as estimated by PLATON.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Preparation and X-ray Structure of 1. Pale-yellowish block-shaped crystals of 1 were prepared by heating the DEF solutions of Mn(NO3)2⋅nH2O and H2NDC at 105 °C for 24 h. The X-ray crystal structure of 1 is shown in Figure . In 1, MnII ions are bridged by carboxylato groups in parts a and b of Chart  to form a 1D MnII chain that extends along the a direction. The intrachain Mn--Mn distance is 3.805 Å. Each MnII is coordinated with six O atoms that belong to four carboxylato groups and one DEF, showing pseudo-octahedral coordination geometry. The carboxylato group O(1)-C(6)-O(2) acts as a tridentate (Chart b) and forms a four-membered chelate ring with Mn [O(1)-Mn-O(2) angle, 56.9°]. The Mn-O distances range from 2.080 to 2.324 Å. The 1D MnII chains are linked one to another via naphthalene rings of NDC2- to form a 3D framework that generates 1D channels of rhombic aperture with diagonal lengths of 21.5 Å × 10.5 Å. The effective window size of the channels is ca. 6.1 Å. The planes made of naphthalene rings of NDC2- run parallel to the (011) and (011̄) planes  and meet across at the 1D MnII chains with a dihedral angle of 50.5°. Although 3D frameworks have been constructed from NDC2- and other metal ions such as Mg2+, Zn2+, and Ni2+, they show structures different from that of 1. The void space of the channels is filled with DEF molecules coordinating MnII ions. The void volume that may be generated after removal of the coordinating DEF molecules is 42.1% of the total volume as estimated by PLATON.

elements.content: Framework 1 is insoluble in water and any organic solvents. TGA data indicate that all coordinating DEF molecules can be removed from 1 at 250 °C (calcd 27%; found 26%) and no chemical decomposition occurs up to 450 °C.

elements.content: Preparation and Properties of 2. By heating of the crystals of 1 at 250 °C under vacuum for 18 h, desolvated solid 2 was prepared, in which DEF molecules coordinating MnII ions are completely removed as evidenced by elemental analysis data, IR spectra, and TGA results. Crystal 2 lost transparency and crystallinity, and thus its X-ray crystal structure could not be determined.
elements.clean_text: Preparation and Properties of 2. By heating of the crystals of 1 at 250 °C under vacuum for 18 h, desolvated solid 2 was prepared, in which DEF molecules coordinating MnII ions are completely removed as evidenced by elemental analysis data, IR spectra, and TGA results. Crystal 2 lost transparency and crystallinity, and thus its X-ray crystal structure could not be determined.

elements.content: In Figure , the XRPD patterns of 1 and 2 are compared. The XRPD pattern of 1 is coincident with the simulated pattern derived from the X-ray crystal data, implying that the bulk sample is the same as the single crystal. The XRPD pattern of desolvated solid 2 is different from that of 1 as well as the simulated pattern of 1 without DEF, indicating that the framework structure changes upon removal of the coordinating DEF molecules. In addition, the XRPD pattern of 1 could not be regenerated even when 2 was immersed in DEF for 24 h to 3 days, indicating that the original structure can hardly be restored once the coordinating DEF molecules are removed. Elemental analysis data indicate that, even after immersion in DEF, the solid does not contain DEF. It is revealed by Rietveld refinement that the dramatic change in the XRPD pattern is caused by the reduction of effective pore apertures. The simulated framework structure of 2 was obtained by Rietveld refinement, which was performed until its XRPD pattern matched with the measured pattern of 2 (see the Supporting Information). The simulated structure indicates that the rhombic aperture of the channel in 2 is significantly squeezed (rhombic angle, 36.3° in 2 vs 50.5° in 1) even though the 3D structure is retained, and thus the effective diameter of the aperture of 2 is reduced (ca. 6 Å in 1 vs 4 Å in 2). Therefore, the difficulty of reintroduction of DEF in the channels in 2 can be explained by the reduced aperture.

elements.content: Recently, we have revealed the reversible rearrangement of the coordination geometry of the metal ions in MOF to a stable coordinatively saturated one upon removal of coordinating solvent molecules. However, in the present study, the possibility of rearrangement of the coordination geometry of MnII from octahedral geometry to a coordinatively saturated trigonal bipyramid instead of a coordinatively unsaturated square pyramid can be ruled out because of the four-membered chelate ring around MnII, based on the model study.

However, in the present study, the possibility of rearrangement of the coordination geometry of MnII from octahedral geometry to a coordinatively saturated trigonal bipyramid instead of a coordinatively unsaturated square pyramid can be ruled out because of the four-membered chelate ring around MnII, based on the model study.

elements.content: Because 2 contains accessible coordination sites on MnII, it adsorbs water vapor when solid 2 is exposed to water vapor for 3 days, which results in a XRPD pattern that is different from either 1 or 2. The shift of the peak at 2θ = 8.8° in 2 to a lower angle region (7.6°) indicates the expansion of the channel size upon exposure to water vapor. The IR spectrum showed a new water peak at 3392 cm-1, and the elemental analysis data indicated that two water molecules per MnII ion were included in the solid. Anal. Calcd for Mn(NDC)·2H2O:  C, 47.23; H, 3.30. Found:  C, 46.59; H, 3.36. It is assumed that a water molecule coordinates to the vacant coordination site of each MnII, and one water molecule per formula unit of 2 is included in the channel, which gives rise to a framework structure different from either 1 or 2. The XRPD pattern of 2 is not altered up to 400 °C (see the Supporting Information), indicating the high thermal stability of framework structure 2.

elements.content: Gas Sorption Properties. To verify the porosity of 2, which contains coordinatively unsaturated MnII ions, the gas sorption capabilities were measured for N2, H2, CO2, and CH4 gases. Interestingly, solid 2 adsorbs these gases with remarkable storage capacity (Figure and Table ). Considering the kinetic diameters of the gases, H2 (2.8 Å), CO2 (3.3 Å), N2 (3.64 Å), and CH4 (3.8 Å), and assuming that the framework structure does not change upon gas adsorption, it can be assumed that the pore opening in 2 is greater than 3.8 Å in diameter.

a  The values are calculated by using the density of 2 (1.06 g/cm3), assuming that the cell volume of 1 is retained in 2, even though the XRPD pattern of 2 is different from that of 1.

Desolvated solid 2 adsorbs N2 gas to show a reversible type I isotherm, indicating the permanent microporosity of 2. The gas sorption shows a little hysteresis between sorption/desorption curves, suggesting a small amount of mesoporosity present in the desolvated material 2, which is attributed to nanosized intercrystalline voids or mesopores within the mosaic pseudomorphs that remain after desolvation. Solid 2 adsorbs 8.8 wt % of N2 at 77 K and 0.95 atm (68 cm3/g at STP). The Langmuir surface area is estimated as 191 m2/g, which is comparable to those of another MnII framework, Mn(HCO2)2·1/3C4H8O2 (ca. 240 m2/g), and of microporous zeolites. The pore volume estimated by applying the Dubinin−Radushkevich equation is 0.068 cm3/g. The removal of small amounts of contaminant gases from H2 is important for the real use of H2 as a fuel, and this selectivity can be applied in the purification of H2 gas. elements.content: We have prepared a 3D open MOF 1 from the simple solvothermal reaction of Mn(NO3)2·nH2O and H2NDC at 105 °C in DEF. Although 1 has no free space because the DEF molecules coordinating MnII ions occupy the channels, they can be removed to obtain desolvated solid 2. Solid 2 contains accessible coordination sites on MnII sites, as evidenced by elemental analysis, IR, TGA, and XRPD data as well as the coordination ability of water molecules. Solid 2 reveals remarkable sorption capabilities for N2, H2, CO2, and CH4 gases and exhibits type I sorption behavior indicative of permanent microporosity. Its adsorption capabilities of N2, CO2, and CH4 gases over H2 gas and that of CO2 over CH4 may be applied in the purification of H2 gas and the removal of CO2 from the natural gas.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have prepared a 3D open MOF 1 from the simple solvothermal reaction of Mn(NO3)2⋅nH2O and H2NDC at 105 °C in DEF. Although 1 has no free space because the DEF molecules coordinating MnII ions occupy the channels, they can be removed to obtain desolvated solid 2. Solid 2 contains accessible coordination sites on MnII sites, as evidenced by elemental analysis, IR, TGA, and XRPD data as well as the coordination ability of water molecules. Solid 2 reveals remarkable sorption capabilities for N2, H2, CO2, and CH4 gases and exhibits type I sorption behavior indicative of permanent microporosity. Its adsorption capabilities of N2, CO2, and CH4 gases over H2 gas and that of CO2 over CH4 may be applied in the purification of H2 gas and the removal of CO2 from the natural gas.

elements.content: An ORTEP drawing of 1, IR spectra and TGA/differential scanning calorimetry plots for 1 and 2, the simulated structure of 2 obtained by Rietveld refinement and its XRPD pattern compared with that of 2, temperature-dependent XRPD patterns of 1, and an X-ray crystallographic file of 1 in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
Preparation of [Mn(NDC)(DEF)] n (1). Mn(NO3)2·nH2O (0.18 g, ca. 1.0 mmol) and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2NDC; 0.22 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in diethylformamide (DEF; 7 mL). The solution was placed in a Teflon vessel within the autoclave, heated at 105 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Pale-yellowish block-shaped crystals were formed, which were filtered off, washed with DEF, and dried in air. Yield:  88%. FT-IR (Nujol mull):  ν C  O(DEF), 1648; ν O  C  O, 1611(s), 1554(s) cm-1. UV/vis (diffuse reflectance, λmax):  330, 285 nm. Anal. Calcd for MnC17H17NO5:  C, 55.15; H, 4.63; N, 3.78. Found:  C, 55.17; H, 4.71; N, 3.50.

Preparation of [Mn(NDC)] n (2). Solid 1 was heated in a Schlenk tube at 250 °C under vacuum for 18 h. FT-IR (Nujol mull):  ν O  C  O, 1602(s), 1552(s) cm-1. UV/vis (diffuse reflectance, λmax):  357, 289 nm. Anal. Calcd for MnC12H6O4:  C, 53.56; H, 2.25; N, 0.00. Found:  C, 52.54; H, 2.43.

The solution was placed in a Teflon vessel within the  autoclave, heated at 105 °C for 24 h, and then cooled to room temperature. cln_elements.content:
Framework 1 is insoluble in water and any organic solvents. TGA data indicate that all coordinating DEF molecules can be removed from 1 at 250 °C (calcd 27%; found 26%) and no chemical decomposition occurs up to 450 °C.

Desolvated solid 2 adsorbs N2 gas to show a reversible type I isotherm, indicating the permanent microporosity of 2. The gas sorption shows a little hysteresis between sorption/desorption curves, suggesting a small amount of mesoporosity present in the desolvated material 2, which is attributed to nanosized intercrystalline voids or mesopores within the mosaic pseudomorphs that remain after desolvation. Solid 2 adsorbs 8.8 wt % of N2 at 77 K and 0.95 atm (68 cm3/g at STP). The Langmuir surface area is estimated as 191 m2/g, which is comparable to those of another MnII framework, Mn(HCO2)2·1/3C4H8O2 (ca. 240 m2/g), and of microporous zeolites. The pore volume estimated by applying the Dubinin−Radushkevich equation is 0.068 cm3/g. With 2, sorption/desorption cycles can be repeated many times, which is contrary to the common MOFs that collapse to a close-packed structure after the gas release.

Solid 2 also adsorbs H2 gas up to 0.57 wt % at 77 K and 1 atm (64 cm3/g at STP). This H2 uptake capacity is much inferior to the materials that we published recently, [Ni(cyclam)(bpydc)] and [Zn4O(NTB)2], which adsorb 1.1 and 1.9 wt % of H2, respectively. The value is rather comparable to that of ZSM-5 (0.7 wt %). Compared to Mg3(NDC)3, which adsorbs 0.46 wt % at 77 K and 880 Torr, the present MnII framework shows 125% better H2 storage capacity. The density of adsorbed H2 at 77 K and 1 atm is 0.052 g/cm3, based on the pore volume estimated from the CO2 sorption data at 195 K. This value is higher than those of any porous MOFs reported so far and is comparable to that of liquid H2 (0.053 g/cm3 at 30 K and 8.1 atm). It should be noted here that the MOFs with CUMSs have been anticipated to show very high H2 sorption because H2 adsorption is regarded as a mixture of physi- and chemisorptions. However, the present result indicates that CUMSs in the MOF do not help the H2 adsorption significantly.

Solid 2 shows a high CO2 sorption capacity even at higher temperatures, 195 and 273 K. It adsorbs 13 wt % of CO2 at 195 K and 1 atm (67.2 cm3/g at STP; Table ). This value is comparable to that (12 wt %, 60.5 cm3/g at STP) of tris-o-phenylenedioxycyclotriphosphazene (TPP) containing 1D channels with a similar diameter, which was reported as a high CO2 storage material. In the CO2 sorption data also, there is some sort of hysteresis that extends to low pressures. This might originate from the swelling of the nonrigid porous structure of 2 or from the strong interactions of CO2 molecules with the host solid 2. The storage capacity at 273 K is also considerably high, adsorbing 6.6 wt % at 1 atm (33.4 cm3/g at STP).

The gas isotherm for CH4 measured at 195 K shows that 2 can store up to 2.7 wt % (37.7 cm3/g at STP), which exceeds those of inorganic zeolites19,22 and organic material TPP (2.4 wt %, 43.9 cm3/cm3, 33.2 cm3/g at STP). At 273 K, it stores 1.3 wt % (17.8 cm3/g at STP), which is higher than ca. 0.8 wt % (at 1 atm and 298 K) of ([{Cu(O2CRCO2)·1/2TED} n ] (R = 4,4‘-C6H4C6H4 or trans-C6H4CHCH), which has a comparable channel size.
